articles.title: A Golden Chapter at Sivagangai – A Farewell Note
articles.shortDescription: A Golden Chapter at Sivagangai – A Farewell Note
articles.longDescription:
Our time at Sivagangai was nothing short of a wonderful experience. We spent 25 memorable months there, from 22nd May 2023 until 27th June 2025, during which Asha served as the District Collector. It was not just a place of stay—it became our extended home, filled with warmth, affection, and unforgettable bonds.


From the very beginning, we were embraced by the love and hospitality of the people of Sivagangai, especially the incredible staff at the Camp Office—both inside and outside the residence. It truly felt like an extended family, with a rich blend of cultures, habits, and emotions. For me and Jayasree, it was as though we gained many sons and daughters during our stay.


Priyatharsini, the team leader of the Camp Office, was our pillar. A dynamic, committed, and highly capable individual, she led the team with unmatched energy and grace. Her discipline, sharp mind, and dedication ensured both the official and residential spaces functioned smoothly. Her care extended beyond duty—she tracked my safety and wellbeing even during my short trips with the concern of a family member. Her family became part of our daily conversations, and we were deeply involved in her daughters’ education, just as we were with our granddaughter Padma. She even arranged regular health check-ups for me, always thoughtful about my well-being.


Balamurugan was the quiet powerhouse behind the seamless running of the house. He had an uncanny ability to spot and resolve every little issue without needing instruction. His day would begin at 6 a.m., preparing a special black tea for me made with palm jaggery, clove, ginger, and cardamom. Breakfast would be ready by 8:30 a.m., and he would ensure Padma’s school bag, shoes, socks, water bottle, and lunch were all perfectly arranged. His energy and work ethic were phenomenal—like an eagle spotting its prey, he identified work before anyone else noticed. He was an immense support to Jayasree.


Subhadra, our cheerful cook, shared a beautiful bond with Padma. They were like friends, spending their evenings together after school. Alongside cooking, Subhadra joined Jayasree and Padma for farm visits, enjoying the harvest and bonding with the goats.


Amutharaj (Amudan) was another of Padma’s close companions. A natural comedian with Vadivelu-style humour, he shared endless light-hearted banter with Padma. She became his tutor in English, Malayalam, music, dance, and more, while he taught her Tamil. A multi-talented soul, Amudan was also a creative mind—crafting school models and DIY projects with flair.


Kaleeswaran, another of Padma’s "students," always brightened her days with his friendly presence.


Veeran, officially the cleaner, was much more—a silent, sincere boy who became a dear family member and a friend to Padma.


Thankaraj and Suresh, who managed the farm, established a warm relationship with us. Suresh, whom Padma fondly called “Sureshannae,” was especially close to her, just like Subhadra.


The dhobi Aashirvadam and wife Bhanu were devout and dutiful, always meticulous with their work.


Muthuraman, one of our drivers, called me Appa like many others. Jayasree would often say, even our own son Sreekuttan doesn't call me in such a soft tone! Ravi, though he left after an accident, and Jayakumar, who served earlier, were also excellent drivers. Jayakumar’s daughters, Ananya and Dhananya, visited us and became good friends with Padma.


Prabhu, Asha’s personal assistant, was a smart and efficient coordinator who handled responsibilities diligently. Ramesh and others too ensured all our needs were met without us even having to ask.


Murugesan, the Collector’s vehicle driver, was more than just a driver—he showed a touching concern for Asha’s daily routine. Sebastian, soft-spoken and kind, also stood out for his caring nature.


In the office, Sreeni, Murugan, and Rajasekharan left lasting impressions with their friendly and committed work.Gunman Vicky, Suresh and others were so close as family members and friends to Padma.Although Alagu was transferred early on, he continued to maintain the relationship even after the transfer.


The person who cleaned the campus, lovingly addressed as "Ayya", worked quietly and devotedly, almost like a saint. His dedication and humility are rare in today’s world.


Even the sentries at the main gate, who changed every day, left fond memories in our hearts.


Other regular visitors included Sumitra, the dance teacher and her family, and the tailor, Mahalekshmi ,all of whom contributed to the warm, homely atmosphere.


And then, there was Padmavathi, the little spark in our lives, who thoroughly enjoyed every moment at the Camp Office. Her bonds with everyone—from the cooks to the drivers—were special and genuine.


Our son, Sreekuttan, currently working in Ramanathapuram, would visit us during holidays. The staff eagerly awaited his visits—he was a natural entertainer, involving everyone in cooking, sports, music, and dance. Though young, he was lovingly called “Annan” by all.


Sub Collector Ayush was like a son to us — a regular visitor to our home who shared many joyful moments, often playing with Padma. We truly miss him too.


Asha got a parent warmth from Justice.M.Chockalingam and A.R.P.Murugesan needs special mention.They considered Padma as their granddaughter and she also had such a warmth sharing the time with them and the hospitality.


The love and affection Padma received at Oxford school also need special mention.The founder of the school Syamala Venkatesan, teachers Pramila,Suba Pavitra,Nisha and staff members made her days at Oxford happy and prosperous


I might have missed names,but all people involved in many ways remain in our heart with colours and sorry if anybody left mentioned.


In total, these two years at Sivagangai will remain a golden period in our lives. We leave with hearts full of gratitude and memories etched deep in our souls.


Farewell, Sivagangai! Thank you for gifting us such a beautiful chapter in our life journey 💛

articles.title: Freedom  -  Part   one
articles.shortDescription:
Freedom is a subject that has been explored in many ways by philosophers across time. But what truly is freedom?
According to Osho, true freedom lies in the ability to say yes, say no, or remain silent—whenever it is necessary. One who can do this is truly free.
articles.longDescription:
When Osho speaks about freedom, he highlights two simple yet powerful words: yes and no. According to him, true freedom lies in the ability to say yes, say no, or remain silent—whenever and however one chooses.


Reading that, I was reminded that yes and no are arguably the two most powerful words in the English language. Interestingly, there is no single-word equivalent for them in Malayalam. I am not sure whether any other language has such precise substitutes either. In Malayalam, yes and no can take on many shades of meaning, and often, a variety of words must be used in their place. This could be seen as a limitation of the language—or perhaps a reflection of cultural nuance.


Yet, Osho’s idea of freedom is, in many ways, only relative. The deeper reality is that nothing in the universe is truly free. Does saying yes, no, or choosing silence truly make one free?


Consider nature: a flowing river, the wind in motion, the vast ocean, or a mountain standing tall—all appear free, yet none are without limitations. Even animals and birds have invisible boundaries. But it is humans who perhaps experience these constraints the most.


Even Osho himself, with all his philosophical insight, was not free from the comforts and dependencies he embraced. When the body is held hostage by hunger, thirst, desire, and greed, how can the soul—or the energy within—experience freedom? Even when this soul escapes the body at the time of death, it does not attain pure independence. That energy still yearns to bind itself again, to enter into something, somewhere.


In essence, the ultimate truth may be this: no one truly desires absolute freedom. And even if they do, they are unlikely to attain it.


(To be continued…)

articles.title: Freedom-part 2--Do humans truly love freedom?
articles.shortDescription:
Do humans truly love freedom?
It's a profound question. Throughout history, humanity has fought to end slavery and oppression — yet many still willingly submit to the chains of caste, religion, and political ideologies. While the human story is, in part, a struggle for liberation, there's also a deep-rooted psychological — perhaps even genetic — tendency in many to seek belonging over freedom. This often manifests as a kind of voluntary servitude. People can become addicted to identity, tradition, and dogma, even when these cause suffering. In many cases, it seems that comfort in the familiar outweighs the desire to be truly free.
articles.longDescription:
When we talk about freedom, we find that it exists on many levels. There are both visible and invisible forms of unfreedom. Domestic animals live with clear restrictions: a bird is confined to its cage, cattle are tethered by a rope, and a dog’s boundaries are set by its owner’s home or field. Even stray dogs, though uncaged, live within the social limits imposed by themselves or human environments. Wild animals, while seemingly free, are still limited by territory and survival needs. Yet, their physical freedom far surpasses that of domesticated animals.


Primitive humans likely experienced this kind of physical freedom in abundance. Perhaps it is due to this genetic memory that modern humans still crave greater freedom.


Over time, those who once roamed freely began forming tribes. In conflicts, the defeated were often enslaved by the victors. Harsh rulers chained the weak, stripping them of physical freedom and selling them like commodities. Slavery, once enforced with iron chains, gradually evolved into more subtle systems. The landlord-tenant model replaced open slavery. Large landowners gave landless people shelter, only to bind them with poverty and dependency. They were denied education, keeping them permanently subservient.


Religion, once introduced, added further layers to these chains. Hierarchies were codified: some declared themselves superior and relegated others to lower castes, entrenching a form of social slavery that persisted for centuries.


With the rise of democracy, some progress was made. However, it has not been absolute. The changes that occurred in Kerala, for instance, have not been mirrored across all of India. In many villages today, caste divisions still prevail. Hindu society remains split into upper castes, backward castes, Scheduled Castes, and Scheduled Tribes. For many, this division results in a deep lack of freedom that persists even today.


Despite the efforts of social reformers—who tried to dismantle these mental chains—the caste-based mindset remains unresolved. Even temples, believed to be the abode of God, uphold this social hierarchy.


All systems of governance, in one way or another, echo the master-slave dynamic. Even democracies, built on the idea of equality, reproduce these patterns. Within political movements, a similar hierarchy exists: central leaders take the place of upper castes, followed by state, district, taluk, and village-level leaders. The masses at the bottom become tools—used by those in power in exchange for minor benefits and freebies.


It is often said that humans are thinking beings. But in truth, many are not. The majority are trapped by the addictions of caste, religion, and politics—and they do not wish to escape. Just as people knowingly continue to use alcohol, tobacco, or drugs despite understanding the harm, so too do they cling to social constructs that limit their freedom.


This is the paradox: even when the chains are invisible, people are reluctant to break free. (To be continued)

articles.title: Freedom -part-3- Unfreedom and religion
articles.shortDescription:
Freedom – Part 3: Unfreedom and  Religion

The most significant trap a human being faces on Earth is religion. Though God is a man-made concept, it has overshadowed humanity and created deep divisions—separating people on every front in the name of faith. To live truly and peacefully on this Earth, one must break free from this trap and seek the truth through their own understanding.
articles.longDescription:
Religion is the first chain that binds human freedom. It is implanted in children at a very young age. The earliest lesson in discrimination is often this: the difference between my religion and yours. In India, this division is most commonly seen between those who go to temples and those who go to mosques or churches.


What children should be taught is this: the Hindu calls it "God", the Christian says "Jehovah", and the Muslim says "Allah". But what they are referring to is essentially the same—a formless, universal force. They should be led to understand that this divine presence is the universe at the macroscopic level and the cell at the microscopic level. That is pure science.


Instead, children are taught to worship idols or prophets. Even though language—words and sentences—is a human creation, we ascribe divine status to them. In this way, religion imparts an unscientific and dogmatic worldview from childhood, shaping minds to be limited and imperfect. As a result, people grow up flawed, live within constraints, and die never having broken free of them.


Parents, even those who know deep down that there is no separate god outside the universe, still teach their children otherwise. They instill the idea of heaven and hell, despite having no evidence or direct experience of either. This act—teaching others what one does not truly know—is the very foundation on which religion thrives.


So, what is religion? Who needs it?


What we really need is to teach one another how to live this human life with mutual love, joy, and responsibility. But most people are not ready for that. And even those who are, often end up isolated. In truth, every child born on this earth is at risk of being trapped by religion. And generation after generation, people unknowingly pass on this mindset to the next.


Instead of urging children to observe, question, and discover truth on their own, we tell them: Don’t think—this is the truth. Follow this path—my path. And so, the journey that the child embarks on is lined with fear and uncertainty. We cut him off from the true source of mental freedom—as if severing him from his mother’s umbilical cord only to bind him again, this time with chains of belief.


An ordinary human being first needs physical freedom, and then seeks mental freedom. If he goes further, he might strive for spiritual freedom—a path far more difficult, and not essential for everyone. Even among ascetics, very few achieve true spiritual freedom. Many spiritual leaders end their lives still entangled in worldly desires, both of the body and the mind. So can we really say they attained spiritual perfection?


True spiritual life belongs only to those rare souls who, having transcended emotional and mental life, renounce everything and return to the forest. These individuals are no longer reformers or leaders; they are solitary seekers. In contrast, those who lead religious institutions or movements often remain bound to the emotional stage of life. They don’t even attain mental freedom. Even ascetics who become social reformers, though they bring great changes to society, often do not attain spiritual freedom. They die burdened by the concerns of the movement they started or the ashram they built.


To truly live a spiritual life, one must walk away from it all—not just physically, but mentally. They must return to nature, to simplicity, to solitude. And how many truly do that?


In the end, those who attain spiritual freedom are souls who die without leaving a mark. Their deaths are not celebrated. They disappear quietly, without followers or monuments. (To be continued)

articles.title: Freedom – Part 4: Protection and Conflict
articles.shortDescription: Conflict is a fundamental force of human life. It operates continuously within the individual—internally and subtly—and this internal struggle reflects on a global, even cosmic, scale. The same conflict that occurs in the human psyche can be seen magnified in the world around us. The Earth itself experiences conflict—in the form of earthquakes, volcanic eruptions, and tsunamis. The same dynamic plays out across the solar system, the Milky Way, and the entire universe.
articles.longDescription:
The various levels of human slavery are intriguing—particularly the kind that individuals willingly impose upon themselves for the sake of material comfort. Among these, the protection offered by religion and caste stands out as especially significant. When a person chooses to live under the shadow of the caste and religion inherited from their parents, they are, in effect, submitting to a system that offers security in the material world. In doing so, they become a slave to that system.


This tendency extends beyond religion and caste. Individuals often become part of organizations or political movements, seeking protection during their education or employment. The sense of material security that these affiliations provide drives them to comply. Even the family is a structure built around the fulfillment of physical needs, offering shelter and emotional support. Friendships, too, function within this same framework of material and emotional convenience.


In essence, modern slavery lies in the way a person, as part of a group, surrenders himself to material desires. What is striking is that most people have no real desire to break free from this form of bondage.


Even when someone transitions from one group to another due to inner turmoil or dissatisfaction, they often find themselves entangled in yet another collective. This new group, too, brings its own share of discomforts and disagreements. People move forward within such systems—sometimes by confronting what they dislike, and at other times by compromising. This cycle is driven by a deep-rooted slave mentality that has been passed down through generations. It's like the dynamic between iron and a magnet—pushing and pulling, separating and reuniting.


This is why personal conflicts are common—within homes, political movements, and organizations. Most individuals navigate life by managing these struggles—either through confrontation or adjustment. The extraordinary mental strength required to live independently, outside these systems, is rare.


Conflict exists at every boundary. More importantly, it also exists within. A nation comprises people of different beliefs, cultures, languages, and ethnicities—leading to both personal and ideological clashes. Conflict is just as prevalent within families. Yet, despite all these frictions, people unite when it comes to shared interests—whether for the sake of the family, the nation, or alliances between like-minded countries. Thus, harmony and conflict constantly alternate, like ebb and flow.


Ultimately, conflict is a fundamental force of human life. It operates continuously within the individual—internally and subtly—and this internal struggle reflects on a global, even cosmic, scale. The same conflict that occurs in the human psyche can be seen magnified in the world around us. The Earth itself experiences conflict—in the form of earthquakes, volcanic eruptions, and tsunamis. The same dynamic plays out across the solar system, the Milky Way, and the entire universe. (To be continued...)

articles.title: The Jamaat case quashed by  the Delhi High Court is a striking example of how urgently our systems need reform.
articles.shortDescription: Reforming our legal and policing systems is not an option — it is an urgent necessity if we wish to build a truly just and developed India.
articles.longDescription:
Five years ago, in the early days of COVID-19, a Tablighi Jamaat congregation was held in Delhi. Following this, the police registered 16 FIRs against 70 Indian citizens for allegedly hosting foreign delegates who attended the gathering, accusing them of violating lockdown orders and health protocols. According to the law, such cases should be investigated swiftly and either taken to trial or closed within a reasonable timeframe — ideally within weeks. Instead, this matter dragged on for five years with no resolution or progress. Finally, on July 16, 2025, the Delhi High Court quashed the charges, bringing an end to years of uncertainty for the accused.


This case raises several critical questions about our justice system:


*Is there no binding time limit for an FIR to be investigated and filed in court? *If an FIR is found to be baseless or wrongly filed, shouldn’t it be withdrawn immediately? *Shouldn’t those falsely implicated receive an official apology and appropriate compensation for the mental agony and reputational damage suffered? *Shouldn’t the officials responsible for such misuse of power and violation of human rights face accountability?


As we dream of becoming a developed nation by 2047, we must ask ourselves: will our justice system continue to remain stuck in this state of delay, inefficiency, and injustice? Or will it become even more unaccountable and oppressive if we do not act now?


Reforming our legal and policing systems is not an option — it is an urgent necessity if we wish to build a truly just and developed India.

articles.title: Eight cities in Kerala are among the top hundred cleanest cities in India
articles.shortDescription: Eight of the top 100 cleanest cities in the Union Ministry of Urban Affairs’ Swachh Survekshan ranking are from Kerala. The commendable efforts made under the leadership of M.B. Rajesh, the Minister for Local Self-Government, deserve special appreciation for this achievement.
articles.longDescription:
It is indeed a matter of pride that eight of the top 100 cleanest cities in the Union Ministry of Urban Affairs’ Swachh Survekshan ranking are from Kerala. The commendable efforts made under the leadership of M.B. Rajesh, the Minister for Local Self-Government, deserve special appreciation for this achievement.


The survey has ranked Mattanur in Kannur as the cleanest city in Kerala. Cities like Guruvayur, Alappuzha, Thiruvananthapuram, Kozhikode, Kollam, Thrissur and Kochi have also secured places in the top 100 list. The dedicated efforts of the officials, municipal authorities, and the countless workers who toiled sincerely at the grassroots level deserve wholehearted praise.


Kerala, with its high population density, continues to face the serious challenge of waste management. While it is heartening that eight of our cities have risen from a past of littered riversides and unclean surroundings to national recognition, many more towns and villages still have a long way to go.


One worrying trend is the growing habit among Malayalis of relying on store-bought cooked food, which is resulting in increased plastic waste. This can be tackled only through greater public awareness and a change in attitudes.


Recognising that tourism is one of our main sources of income, Kerala must strive to emulate cities like Indore — which has consistently topped the cleanliness rankings — by allocating more funds in the budget and ensuring robust public participation in waste management initiatives.


Let us hope we continue on this path with renewed resolve and collective responsibility.

articles.title: Power, Corruption, and the Weakness of Democracy
articles.shortDescription: In a democracy, deficiencies in the legal system and judiciary can create avenues for the powerful to avoid facing justice
articles.longDescription:
Democracy is undoubtedly the best system of governance, but the protection it often extends to criminals, murderers, corrupt politicians, the wealthy, and the unscrupulous tarnishes its glory. Democracy can only be truly beautiful when it brings together the best features of all good systems in the world. The greatest weakness of democracy lies in its flawed legal system


Under dictatorships or monarchies, the legal machinery often acts swiftly and decisively, supported by strict laws that instill genuine fear of punishment. In democracies, however, the law is frequently undermined and treated with contempt by those who know how to manipulate it.


I say this today because of the glaring example of the corruption cases involving former Bihar Chief Minister and Union Railway Minister Lalu Prasad Yadav. The infamous fodder scam of the 1990s, the IRCTC scam between 2004 and 2009, the land-for-jobs scam, and allegations of massive benami properties together amount to scams worth hundreds of crores of rupees. Yet, a person facing such grave charges is out on bail on health grounds, remains politically active, and continues to evade justice while endless investigations drag on aimlessly.


This sorry state of affairs exposes the cracks in our legal system. Even in the ‘developed India’ we dream of for 2047, cases like these may still linger unresolved, reminding us that sometimes all we can do is stand by and watch—powerless to see the rule of law prevail.

articles.title: The history of Kerala CPM will have to be recorded as before and after V.S.
articles.shortDescription: V.S. Achuthanandan passed away at the age of one hundred and two, fulfilling the fullness of a human life. V.S., who led a tireless and restless life until the age of ninety-five, had been resting for the past six years. He left us yesterday. We see V.S. as the last leader in the EMS and Nayanar tradition — leaders who believed that at least some Marxian ideals could be practically implemented and who genuinely worked for it. V.S. was a leader who followed Maoist approaches, giving prime importance to farmers, workers, and land reforms. He was a strict leader who took an uncompromising stand against corruption — a staunch communist who never wavered from his beliefs.
articles.longDescription:
V.S. Achuthanandan passed away at the age of one hundred and two, fulfilling the fullness of a human life. V.S., who led a tireless and restless life until the age of ninety-five, had been resting for the past six years. He left us yesterday. We see V.S. as the last leader in the EMS and Nayanar tradition — leaders who believed that at least some Marxian ideals could be practically implemented and who genuinely worked for it. V.S. was a leader who followed Maoist approaches, giving prime importance to farmers, workers, and land reforms. He was a strict leader who took an uncompromising stand against corruption — a staunch communist who never wavered from his beliefs.


Yet, like many communist leaders, he too faced rejection from within the party. With the advent of globalization and privatization, the communist movement in India transformed significantly. The party leadership gradually came into the hands of millennial Marxists — a new generation that began prioritizing the needs and interests of the middle class and the affluent. In these times, when people at all levels of the party seem to chase wealth and power, we can clearly divide the history of the party into two phases: before and after V.S.


When I worked at Kerala House and the Malayalam Mission, I spoke to V.S. only on official matters. His style was to listen intently and reply in a few measured words. I still remember that there was factionalism among the staff at Kerala House — only those considered V.S.’s supporters could freely access his room.


In 1996, after the Politburo meeting that followed V.S.’s defeat in Mararikulam — despite the Left Front securing a clear majority — a historic discussion took place. On the morning before leaving for the airport, E.K. Nayanar, Pinarayi Vijayan, and V.S. sat together in room number 101 of Kerala House for a secret meeting. I remember Vijaya Mohan of Malayala Manorama and I discussed what might have transpired there. None of us imagined that it was the meeting where they decided not to make Susheela Gopalan the Chief Minister, and instead Nayanar — who hadn’t even contested — would take charge. Politics can create unexpected miracles. Such miracles include V.S. becoming Chief Minister at the age of eighty-two, Pinarayi stepping into that role later, and the continuation of that administration.


Although many labelled V.S. as regressive for giving priority to the environment over certain development activities, it is noteworthy that several key developmental initiatives were undertaken during his tenure as Chief Minister. He never hesitated to act when convinced of what was right. History has marked many instances where V.S. displayed extraordinary conviction — from his fight against corruption to his progressive stance on women’s issues.


No one is perfect, not even V.S. But we bid farewell to the beauty of that imperfection.

articles.title: When Justice Sleeps: The Unsettling Legacy of  Mumbai Bombing and Malegaon Cases
articles.shortDescription: If justice continues to falter in  grave cases, the nation risks losing more than just legal credibility — it erodes public faith in the very idea of accountability. The Justice is delayed , denied and ultimately disrespected .
articles.longDescription:
The long-drawn trials in the Malegaon 2008 blast and the 2006 Mumbai train bombings have exposed deep cracks in India’s criminal justice system. While hundreds lost their lives or limbs, and families waited for closure, what they received instead were hostile witnesses, changing investigative narratives, and endless procedural delays.


The acquittals, bail grants, and judicial leniency shown to prime accused — some now sitting in public office — raise troubling questions. Were the initial charges weak, the evidence fabricated, or the system simply unwilling to carry cases to a just conclusion?


When the police fail to investigate with integrity, and courts hesitate to convict where evidence once seemed strong, justice itself becomes the casualty. The signal sent is dangerous: that even terror cases can be politicized, manipulated, or quietly buried under paperwork and time.


If justice continues to falter in such grave cases, the nation risks losing more than just legal credibility — it erodes public faith in the very idea of accountability. Here, the Justice is delayed , denied and ultimately disrespected .

articles.title: Rethinking Vacations and Exams in Kerala Schools
articles.shortDescription: There is a serious discussion in Kerala about replacing the traditional summer vacation with a monsoon vacation. This is my opinion on the changes that have already been discussed at various levels
articles.longDescription:
An idea recently put forward by Kerala Education Minister V. Sivankutty has sparked much discussion. The core of the debate is whether the traditional midsummer vacation should be replaced with a monsoon vacation. While many who prefer conventional methods opposed this change, those who welcome innovation supported it. I too stand with those who favor change. Since the real impact of such a reform can be known only after implementation, the practical approach is to try it out, even if there is initial resistance.


A notable suggestion came from Kanthapuram, who proposed combining the scorching month of May with the devastating monsoon of June to form a single vacation. He also suggested reducing the number of examinations from three to two. Both are valuable ideas. I would like to extend this thought further with a slightly modified proposal.


If the end-of-year examination is deemed necessary, it should be conducted by the beginning of March, with results published before the end of that month. The new academic year should start on April 1 and continue until April 30. Then, from May 1 to June 30, students can enjoy a combined summer–monsoon vacation. Classes can resume on July 1.


Examinations should also move beyond the outdated practice of testing mere memory. Instead of Onam, Christmas, and annual exams, logical assessments based on the lessons taught each month should be conducted. The average of these scores can determine a child’s progress. If two major exams are considered unavoidable, they should be designed with logical, open-book questions rather than rote-based ones. The goal must be to develop a child’s ability to analyze and apply knowledge, not just memorize and reproduce it.


A balanced grading system could be created by combining the scores from monthly exams, a half-yearly exam, and the annual exam. At the same time, there should be a transparent mechanism to review complaints regarding marks in both monthly and annual assessments. For this transformation to succeed, teachers must be adequately empowered and trained. Steps to strengthen and equip them should go hand-in-hand with academic reforms.
